Authors: Mae J., Oey E., Kristiady F.S.
Title: IoT based body weight tracking system for obese adults in Indonesia using realtime database
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mae, J., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Oey, E., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kristiady, F.S., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Obesity has become a serious issue in many countries with increasing prevalence every year. People with obesity has higher risk for several serious health complications and on a larger scale, this could bring negative implications for economic growth and human wellbeing of a nation. Many studies have been conducted to overcome this issue and some suggested that regular self weighing could promote weight loss and weight maintenance. Based on those findings, a body weight tracking system is made as an approach from technological side. The purpose of this system is to raise health awareness by using easy-to-use technology to monitor user weight from time to time. The system consists of a realtime database, a smartphone application, and a modified digital weight scale. The weight scale is tested to have more than 99% accuracy and can active for estimated 40 hours of usage, while the realtime database storage for this implementation is adequate for more than half a million users. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: IoT; obesity; realtime database; weight tracking
Index Keywords: Anthropometry; Database systems; Economics; Health risks; Internet of things; Nutrition; Tracking (position); Economic growths; Health awareness; Health complications; Human wellbeing; obesity; Real-time database; Smart-phone applications; Weight maintenance; Scales (weighing instruments)

Authors: Prabowo R.E., Julian N., Mae J., Susanto R., Hedwig R.
Title: Navigation assistant for vision impaired people using ultra sonic (sonar vision) and global positioning system (GPS)
Source title: IOP Conference Series: Earth and Environmental Science
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Prabowo, R.E., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Julian, N., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Mae, J., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Susanto, R., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hedwig, R., Computer Engineering Department, Faculty of Engineering, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: People with low vision usually use stick to find their way or to face an obstacle in front of them. However, this detection only can be felt as long as the length of the stick from its handle is as far as the reach of the hand. Seeing this limitation, a set of sonar vision was made using sonar sensor, which equipped as a wristwatch and a buckle of a belt. The sonar vision was designed to detect an obstacle for up to 3 meters away. A hundred low vision people already got the benefit of this system, which 84% of them felt that the sonar vision helped them in the navigation. The new design based on the feedback is presented in this paper, which is equipped with GPS for positioning information. © 2020 Published under licence by IOP Publishing Ltd.
Author Keywords: blind; GPS; low vision; obstacle detection; sonar
Index Keywords: Felt; Felts; Obstacle detectors; Sonar; blind; Low vision; Obstacle detection; Positioning information; Sonar sensor; Vision impaired; Global positioning system

Title: Simple road side detection and tracking on embedded PC
Source title: Proceedings - 2018 IEEE 15th International Workshop on Advanced Motion Control, AMC 2018
Affiliations: Electrical Engineering Department, Universitas Indonesia, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Muis, A., Electrical Engineering Department, Universitas Indonesia, Indonesia; Mae, J., Electrical Engineering Department, Universitas Indonesia, Indonesia
Abstract: Road tracking is highly required to drive vehicle autonomously. However, the tracking system must deal with two main constraints; real-time computation and limited computing power. Among various efforts, a road side detection is an alternative to provide road tracking. However, dealing road side detection with those constraints is still challenging. Therefore, this paper proposes a simple road side detection and tracking which is adequate for low cost embedded PC. Mainly, the road appearance has different texture to the road side. An algorithm is developed by searching the changing texture from the center to the road side. Here, this paper observes road existence about half part of road appearance on image. Which is about 10 ~ 14m ahead. It depends on perspective appearance of hardware setup. This interested region is observed horizontally on certain consecutive distance. Later, projection on image plane of each corresponding distance are observed for changing texture. The proposed method is evaluated within the first 500 consecutive image frames from the starting time on moving car. Four trials with different tracks are considered for evaluation. The algorithm was successfully run with 640x480 image resolution on raspberry Pi with accuracy 87%. The image was taken with 15fps and the computation for road detection was not more than 10ms. © 2018 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Detection; Embedded PC; Road side; Tracking
Index Keywords: Error detection; Image resolution; Motion control; Surface discharges; Computing power; Consecutive images; Detection and tracking; Embedded PCs; Interested regions; Real-time computations; Road detection; Tracking system; Roads and streets

Title: Real-time lane recognition and position estimation for small vehicle
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Tan, S., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Mae, J., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper discuss the algorithm and real-time implementation of road lane detection and recognition in a miniature vehicle. The research aimed to find an algorithm with low calculation cost intended for real-time implementation in low power and small size embedded system. The algorithm employs probabilistic Hough transform to detect lines and inverse perspective mapping method to recognize the simulated road lane in bird's view. By using the known distance between lane markings and its color, the algorithm managed to achieve high recognition and vehicle position estimation accuracy. Implementation on an arm-based small processing board yielded a position estimation rate of more than 4 Hz. © 2013 IIJ.
Author Keywords: Inverse perspective mapping; Lane recognition; Real-time embedded system; Vehicle position estimation

Title: Low cost vision-based real-time lane recognition and lateral pose estimation
Source title: Proceeding - IEEE CYBERNETICSCOM 2013: IEEE International Conference on Computational Intelligence and Cybernetics
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Tan, S., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Agnes, Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Mae, J., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Real-time road lane recognition and position estimation algorithm in small vehicle is generally limited by the amount of processing power available. The goal of this research is to develop a light-weight algorithm to recognize a pair of road lane markers using computer vision and to estimate the vehicle position relative to the lane markers. The road lane recognition algorithm uses inverse perspective mapping of detected lines to speed-up recognition of the lane markers pair, and then a color matching stage is employed to reduce false recognition. The algorithm is implemented in a small battery-powered processing unit and evaluated in a miniature four-wheel vehicle to recognize a pair of lane markers on the floor and to estimate the vehicle's pose on the floor relative to the lane markers. The algorithm managed to estimate the lateral position and the orientation of the vehicle with accuracy about 1.5 cm and 2 degree respectively, and an estimation rate of 2.7 Hz. © 2013 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Inverse perspective mapping; lane recognition; real-time system; vehicle pose estimation
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Electric vehicles; Floors; Mapping; Real time systems; Roads and streets; Inverse perspective mappings; Lane recognition; Lateral positions; Position estimation; Processing power; Road lane recognition; Vehicle pose; Vehicle position; Algorithms

Authors: Mae J., Hazor A., Wiryanto N.K., Oey E., Hedwig R.
Title: Modified line-maze algorithm for mobile robot navigation
Affiliations: Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jl K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mae, J., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jl K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Jakarta 11480, Indonesia; Hazor, A., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jl K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Jakarta 11480, Indonesia; Wiryanto, N.K., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jl K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Jakarta 11480, Indonesia; Oey, E., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jl K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Jakarta 11480, Indonesia; Hedwig, R., Computer Engineering Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jl K.H. Syahdan No. 9, Jakarta 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This paper will discuss the design of a fully autonomous fire fighting robot which is able to navigate through a maze and navigate back to it s starting position. The maze is designed with few obstacles that must be avoided by the robot while navigating. A Modified Line-Maze Algorithm is introduced to navigate the robot through the maze and reach a fire lit at different locations on the arena in the form of candles, and will blow it off using a fan. The concepts implemented in this robot are differential drive control, obstacle avoidance, environmental sensing, and electronic circuit design. The sensors used in the robot are PING ultrasonic sensor, infrared ranger, digital compass, and UVTron flame sensor. The robot is being controlled by AVR ATMega128 16 MIPS and is designed according to the rules laid down by, and to compete in the Indonesia Intelligent Robot Contest (KRCI) in 2012. Before the contest, the robot is tested to solve the maze problem and the result shows that the fastest time needed for robot to extinguish the fire and return to its starting point is 48.46 seconds and the false reading has been reduced as high as 99% compared to the previous design [1]. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Fire-fighting robot; Infrared sensor; KRCI; Modified line-maze algoritm; Ultrasonic sensor; UV sensor
